taskDescription: The models you made in Levels 1, 2 and 3 predicted that the zebra population would increase indefinitely.  Clearly, that wonu2019t happen because zebras will starve to death where there are too many of them for the amount of grassland they occupy.  Ecologists use u201ccarrying capacityu201d to refer to the maximum population that can be supported by a given habitat.   The model below assumes that the death probability rises as population increases until the death probability equals the birth probability when the population equals the carrying capacity.  At that point, annual deaths equal annual births, so the population stops growing.
- The zebra population is 20 in the first year (1950).
- Births and deaths are the only change in the population.  Immigration and emigration do not occur.
- The number of zebra births each year is the zebra birth probability times the zebra population.
- The probability of a zebra giving birth each year is 50%.
- The number of zebra deaths each year is the zebra death probability times the zebra population.
- Zebra death probability = zebra birth probability * (zebra population / carrying capacity).
- Carrying capacity is 500 (for zebras living in Tanzania, Africa).

givenModelNodes.name: Zebra Population
givenModelNodes.description: The number of zebras in the population

givenModelNodes.name: Zebra Births
givenModelNodes.description: The number of zebras born each year

givenModelNodes.name: Zebra Deaths
givenModelNodes.description: The number of zebra that die each year

givenModelNodes.name: Zebra Birth Probability
givenModelNodes.description: The probability of a zebra giving birth during the year

givenModelNodes.name: Zebra Death Probability
givenModelNodes.description: The probability of a zebra dying during the year

givenModelNodes.name: Zebra Carrying Capacity
givenModelNodes.description: The number of zebras the environment can support
